slide.title: Changes This Year ...
slide.p: A few things are changing this term, as a result of some Learning Initiative workshops and redevelopment over the first half of this year. These have led to some rethinking of COMP4711 and how it is presented and delivered...

slide.title: Backwards Design
slide.p: It all starts with the "story" behind the course, and what I want you to get out of it ... what you see as the "course goals" in the course outline.

ul.li: The "story" incorporates the "big picture", and stated as well as unstated learning outcomes.
From this, determine the real-world "evidence", and how an employer would assess your abilities.
These lead to a clearer expression of the learning outcomes
... which need suitable assessments (assignments, exams, etc)
... and which lead to a sequence of instruction

slide.title: Course Outcomes
slide.p: See the "course goals" section in the course outline.

ol.li: Build a moderate MVC web application using a suitable framework
Build distributed capabilities into an MVC web application
Demonstrate proper team collaboration for webapp development

slide.title: Flipped Learning
slide.p: Weekly readings will be assigned, starting with the second week, following a "flipped" learning model.

You are to read these lessons and answer a quiz/questionnaire, by the evening before that week's "lecture". The "lecture" will address unclear topics, per your feedback, and discuss issues relevant to that week's topics/outcomes.
Yes, you do the "lesson" on your own, and the "homework" during lab.

slide.title: Flipped LMS
slide.p: Desire2Learn (D2L) is a very comprehensive Learning Management System (LMS).
It is both flexible and inflexible at the same time, and expects content to be re-expressed inside its awkward & clunky confines.

A flipped LMS, on the other hand, lives independently of D2L, and is whatever suits the tech-savvyness of the instructor. These are typically open-source, flat file driven, and stored/collaborated on, using an online repository.

ul.li: Organizer, lessons, tutorials, and lab/assignment writeups all on our course hub.
Material can be viewed as slideshow, webpage, or downloaded as PDF.
Code examples or starter projects all shared as Github repositories, to be forked.
Assignments done in teams, on github; readme (with links) is submitted to D2L dropbox

slide.title: Grading
slide.p: Attendance expected, missing more than 2 labs => U
Labs: individual or varying pairs, rubric-based assessment
Assignments: teams of 2-5, each building on the previous, rubric-based assessment

ul.li: Required proficiency: programming, Java (COMP2526) or C (COMP2510)
Somewhat proficient: O-O programming, O-O analysis and design (patterns!)
Assumed: English, computer literacy, basic math, basic relational database, basic networks, basic algorithms, basic HTML/CSS
